description.p: You can make a Gunslinger quickly by following these suggestions. First, Dexterity should be your highest ability score, followed by Intelligence. Then pick the outlander background.
Some kinds of firearms are Heavy, so be mindful of your choice of weaponry if you are playing a Small race.
As an gunslinger, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per gunslinger level after 1st
Tools: Tinker’s tools + one other tool of your choice
Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Athletics, Sleight of Hand, History, Investigation, Perception, Intimidation, and Survival

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) a Crossbow or (b) one firearm (see appendix A), and 20 pieces of ammunition
(a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack

description.p: Alternatively, you may start with 5d4 x 10 gold to buy starting equipment.

tr.td: Close Shave, Fighting Style, Firearm Proficiency

description.p: To qualify for a new class, you must meet the ability score prerequisites for both your current class and your new one.
Ability Score Minimum: Dexterity 13 or Intelligence 13
When you gain a level in a class other than your first, you only gain some of that class’s starting proficiencies.

You have an uncanny knack for getting out of the way of ranged attacks. When you are hit by a ranged attack, you can use your reaction to move 5 feet in any direction and gain a bonus to your AC equal to your proficiency modifier against the triggering attack. Instead of moving 5 feet, you can also choose to drop prone.

sheet.description: When you are hit by a ranged attack, you can move 5 feet in any direction and gain a +{{proficiency}} bonus to your AC against the triggering attack. Instead of moving 5 feet, you can also choose to drop prone.

description.p: You are proficient in the construction, maintenance, and operation of firearms. (See Appendix A: Firearms for detailed firearm information.)

div.p: Not every campaign setting has firearms as readily available and purchasable items. Consult with your DM about how firearms fit in their world.

description.p: At 1st level, you adopt a certain style of fighting. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

When you take the attack action with a light ranged weapon that you are holding in one hand, you can use your bonus action to attack with a different light ranged weapon you are holding in your other hand.
You gain a +2 bonus to attack rolls you make with ranged weapons.

Being within 5 feet of a hostile creature does not impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls. Your ranged attacks ignore half and three-quarters cover against targets that are within 30 feet of you. You have a +1 bonus to attack rolls with ranged attacks.

You learn one trick shot from the Trick Shooter’s list of trick shots. Once per rest, you can use this trick shot without spending it’s grit cost. Once you have used this trick shot, you can’t use it again in this way until you finish a short or long rest.

During a short rest, you can spend time cleaning and practicing with a single firearm of your choice. Your dedication to this weapon allows you to use it more effectively. You gain a +3 to damage rolls with this weapon, and have disadvantage on all attack rolls with any firearm that is not your dedicated weapon.
While you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier.
At the start of your turn, you can reduce your movement speed to 0 to gain a +2 to damage rolls for rifles.
When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for a ranged attack you make with a shotgun, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or 2.
You can draw a weapon that has the thrown property as part of taking the attack you make with the weapon.
In addition, when you hit with a thrown weapon, you gain a +1 bonus to the damage roll.
Your unarmed strikes can deal bludgeoning damage equal to 1d6 + your Strength modifier. If you strike with two free hands, the d6 becomes a d8.

When you successfully start a grapple, you can deal 1d4 bludgeoning damage to the grappled creature. Until the grapple ends, you can deal this damage to the creature whenever you hit it with a melee attack.

Starting at 2nd level, you have a well of unwavering resolve called Grit. In times of extreme stress you have found that you can push yourself beyond your normal limitations, performing acts of incredible skill and perseverance. Your gunslinger level determines the number of grit points you have, as shown in the Grit Points column of the Gunslinger table.

You can spend these points to fuel various class and subclass features. When you spend a grit point, it is unavailable until you finish a short or long rest, at the end of which you regain all expended grit.
Some of your grit features require your target to make a saving throw against the feature’s effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:
Grit save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
You can spend 1 grit point to give yourself advantage on a Constitution saving throw.

As a bonus action, you can spend 1 grit point to take a moment and steady your aim, ensuring your shots do more damage. Until the end of the current turn, whenever you hit a creature with a ranged weapon attack with a rifle, you deal additional damage equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).
After you take the Attack action on your turn, you can spend 1 grit point to make up to two ranged weapon attacks with a pistol as a bonus action.
You can spend 1 grit point to take the Dash or Disengage action as a bonus action on your turn.
As a bonus action, you can spend 1 grit point to reload a single shell into a shotgun you are holding and immediately make a ranged weapon attack with it.
You can spend 1 grit point to prevent attacking at long range from imposing disadvantage on your attack rolls until the end of the current turn.

description.p: At 3rd level, you are led either by your own choices or by the harsh world around you to follow a Calling which shapes how you approach your craft. Your calling grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, 15th, and 18th levels.
Your calling options are shown here.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.

At 4th level, you gain a specialization of your choice. Your specialization options are detailed at the end of the class description, and are indexed in Appendix B. When you gain certain gunslinger levels, you gain additional specializations of your choice, as shown in the Specializations Known column of the Gunslinger table.
Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the specializations you know and replace it with another specialization that you could learn at that level.

div.p: Specializations can be restricted by three things: Calling, Level, and Weapon Type. If a specialization is restricted by level, you must be a gunslinger of that level or higher to take that specialization. If a specialization is restricted to a certain calling, only gunslingers of that calling can choose it. If a specialization is restricted to certain type of weapon, you must be using a weapon of that type to gain it’s benefit.

description.p: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, when you take the Attack action on your turn.

sheet.description: You can attack twice, instead of once, when you take the Attack action on your turn.

description.p: You have refined the process by which you craft your special ammunitions. Starting at 6th level, your ranged weapon attacks are counted as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

sheet.description: Your ranged weapon attacks are counted as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

description.p: Beginning at 7th level, when you succeed on a Dexterity saving throw, you can use your reaction to make a single ranged weapon attack against a creature within range.

sheet.description: When you succeed on a Dexterity saving throw, you can make a single ranged weapon attack against a creature within range.

description.p: Starting at 7th level, when an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to half the attack’s damage against you.

sheet.description: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can half the attack’s damage against you.

description.p: Your ability to anticipate your opponent’s next move borders on clairvoyance. Beginning at 9th level, you gain a bonus to all ranged weapon attack rolls equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

sheet.description: You gain a +{{int-mod:min-one}} bonus to all ranged weapon attack rolls.

description.p: Beginning at 11th level, as long as you have at least 1 unspent grit point, you can reload a firearm as a bonus action instead of an action. Additionally, you can ignore the loading property of weapons.

sheet.description: As long as you have at least 1 unspent grit point, you can reload a firearm as a bonus action instead of an action. Additionally, you can ignore the loading property of weapons.

description.p: Starting at 13th level, when you have unspent grit points equal to or less than your Intelligence modifier and you score a critical hit against a creature, you regain 1 expended grit point.

sheet.description: When you have unspent grit points equal to or less than {{intelligence:modifier}} and you score a critical hit against a creature, you regain 1 expended grit point.

description.p: At 14th level, when you roll a saving throw, as long as you have at least 1 unspent grit point, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

sheet.description: When you roll a saving throw, as long as you have at least 1 unspent grit point, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

description.p: At 17th level, when you roll a 20 on a ranged weapon attack roll, you can spend 3 grit points to have the creature make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save the target takes an additional 6d8 piercing damage, or half as much additional damage on a success.

sheet.description: When you roll a 20 on a ranged weapon attack roll, you can spend 3 grit points to have the creature make a Constitution saving throw (DC {{grit:save-dc}}). On a failed save the target takes an additional 6d8 piercing damage, or half as much additional damage on a success.

description.p: At 20th level, you can push past all your limits and unleash your true potential for all to see. As a bonus action, you become an unstoppable whirlwind of bullets and blood.
For 1 minute, you gain the following benefits:

ul.li: You immediately regain up to 4 spent grit points
You reduce all damage taken by an amount equal to your proficiency modifier
The grit cost of all abilities is reduced by 1.

description.p: Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: You become an unstoppable whirlwind of bullets and blood. You immediately regain up to 4 spent grit points. You reduce all damage taken by an amount equal to your proficiency modifier. The grit cost of all abilities is reduced by 1.

description.p: "It doesn’t matter what the enemy’s pieces are if you own the board." — Eliza Weaver, half-elf arcane gunner and avid chess player.
You are a master of positioning and tactics, molding the battlefield and yourself to always have the upper hand.

When you reach 3rd level, you augment your gunslinging prowess with the ability to cast spells. See chapter 10 of the PHB for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the wizard spell list.
You learn two cantrips of your choice from the wizard spell list. You learn an additional wizard cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

The Arcane Gunner Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your wizard spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell shield and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast shield using either slot.

You know three 1st-level wizard spells of your choice, two of which you must choose from the transmutation and conjuration spells on the wizard spell list. The Spells Known column of the Arcane Gunner Spellcasting table shows when you learn more wizard spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be a transmutation or conjuration spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.
The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can come from any school of magic.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the wizard spells you know with another spell of your choice from the wizard spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be a conjuration or transmutation spell, unless you’re replacing the spell you gained at 3rd, 8th, 14th, or 20th level from any school of magic.

Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells, since you learn your spells through study and memorization. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when making an attack roll with a wizard spell. Any spell that refers to your Spell save DC uses your Grit save DC.
Spell Save DC (your Grit Save DC) = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

You are never truly deprived of your weapon. When you adopt this Calling at 3rd level, you learn how to magically conjure ranged weapons and ammunition. As a bonus action, you can summon a single ranged weapon into your hands. If it uses ammunition, it is loaded.
You can conjure up to two weapons in this way. If you attempt to conjure a third, the first weapon disappears.

sheet.description: You can summon a single ranged weapon into your hands. If it uses ammunition, it is loaded. You can conjure up to two weapons in this way.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, when you cast a spell that has a casting time of one action, your gun regains bullets equal to the level of the spell you cast, up to its maximum reload value. Alternatively, you can conjure up to two thrown weapons into your hands, or up to 4 arrows or bolts into your quiver. All items conjured in this way disappear after 1 minute.

sheet.description: When you cast a spell that has a casting time of one action, your gun regains bullets equal to the level of the spell you cast, up to its maximum reload value. Alternatively, you can conjure up to two thrown weapons into your hands, or up to 4 arrows or bolts into your quiver. All items conjured in this way disappear after 1 minute.

description.p: At 10th level, you gain the ability to conjure wooden barriers on the battlefield. As a bonus action, you can expend 1 grit point to conjure a piece of wooden cover in an unoccupied space adjacent to you. The barrier grants half cover against ranged attacks to those standing behind it, and three-quarters cover against ranged attacks to those lying prone behind it.
The barrier occupies the square it is conjured in, and can be attacked and destroyed. It has an AC of 15 and 25 hit points. The cover lasts for one minute, or until you dismiss it as an action.

sheet.description: You can conjure a wooden barrier that grants half cover against ranged attacks to those standing behind it, and three-quarters cover against ranged attacks to those lying prone behind it. The barrier occupies the square it is conjured in, and can be attacked and destroyed. It has an AC of 15 and 25 hit points. The cover lasts for one minute, or until you dismiss it as an action.

description.p: At 15th level, you learn how to accelerate your perception of the world around you in response to sudden threats. As a reaction when you are targeted by an attack roll, you can spend 1 grit point to give all attack rolls against you Disadvantage until the end of the current turn.

sheet.description: When you are targeted by an attack roll, you can give all attack rolls against you Disadvantage until the end of the current turn.

description.p: Starting at 18th level, as an action you can expend 4 grit points to conjure a stationary gun turret in an unoccupied space adjacent to you. Alternatively, you can conjure this turret in the same space as a piece of cover you have conjured. You can only have one turret conjured at a time. A turret lasts for one minute, until you dismiss it as an action, or until you spend grit to conjure a new turret.

You can concentrate on the turret as on a spell. While you do so, ammunition is continuously conjured into the waiting chamber. If concentration is lost, the turret cannot be fired again until you use an Action to regain concentration.
The turret cannot be fired while prone.
The turret has the following statblock:

tr.td: Ammunition (range 200), loading, penetrating, siege weapon, two-handed

While you do so, ammunition is continuously conjured into the waiting chamber. If concentration is lost, the turret cannot be fired again until you use an Action to regain concentration. The turret cannot be fired while prone.

description.p: Fortune and glory, kid.
~ Han Solo, Charlatan Gunslinger
Beginning at 3rd level, when you use your action to take the Dodge or Disengage actions, you can make a single ranged weapon attack as a bonus action.

Additionally, when initiative is rolled and you aren’t surprised, you can use your reaction to move 10 feet as part of the initiative check. Alternatively, you can spend 1 grit point and move up to your walking speed instead.

sheet.description: When you use your action to take the Dodge or Disengage actions, you can make a single ranged weapon attack as a bonus action. Additionally, when initiative is rolled and you aren’t surprised, you can use your reaction to move 10 feet as part of the initiative check. Alternatively, you can spend 1 grit point and move up to your walking speed instead.

description.p: When you adopt this calling at 3rd level, you become proficient in Deception and Slight of Hand. If you are already proficient in these skills, you can gain expertise in one of them.

At 6th level, you learn how to get under your opponent’s skin. As an action, you can target a number of creatures up to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) within 60 feet of you, spending 1 grit point per creature. Each creature must make a Wisdom saving throw or be taunted by you for 1 minute. For the duration, a taunted creature has disadvantage on attack rolls against creatures other than you.

This effect ends early if you attack a creature not currently taunted by you, if a creature friendly to you damages the target, or casts a harmful spell on it, or if you end your turn more than 60 feet away from a target. An affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the condition on a success.

sheet.description: You target up to {{int-mod:min-one}} creatures within 60 feet of you. Each creature must make a Wisdom saving throw (DC {{grit:save-dc}}) or be taunted by you for 1 minute. For the duration, a taunted creature has disadvantage on attack rolls against creatures other than you. This effect ends early if you attack a creature not currently taunted by you, if a creature friendly to you damages the target, or casts a harmful spell on it, or if you end your turn more than 60 feet away from a target. An affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the condition on a success.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, when an attack misses you, you can move 5 feet without provoking opportunity attacks. This movement is subtracted from your available movement on your next turn.

sheet.description: When an attack misses you, you can move 5 feet without provoking opportunity attacks. This movement is subtracted from your available movement on your next turn.

description.p: Beginning at 15th level, you gain the ability to inspire confidence in your allies. As an action, you and a number of creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) become immune to the frightened condition and gain temporary hit points equal to half your gunslinger level (rounded down).

sheet.description: You and up to {{int-mod:min-one}} creatures become immune to the frightened condition and gain {{level:gunslinger:half}} temporary hit points.

description.p: At 18th level, you learn how to fool your enemies into believing you have met an untimely end. When you are below half of your maximum hit points and you take damage, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to the damage of the attack and pretend the blow killed you. You fall prone and make a Deception (Charisma) check with advantage contested against your opponent’s Passive Insight (10 + their Wisdom modifier). On a success, they believe you were killed and and will behave accordingly. If you attack a deceived creature, you have advantage on the attack roll, and all creatures who can see you are no longer deceived.

This charade does not hold up under inspection. If a creature uses their action to Investigate your body, they will discover you are still alive. Creatures that discover your deception, or witness you attack while deceived are unlikely to fall for it a second time.
Once you use this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

div.p: Although there is no mechanical benefit to tricking your fellow players along with the enemy, it sure would be funny if you started rolling up a new character after ’dying,’ wouldn’t it? Just maybe don’t let the cleric get themselves killed trying to save you.

You fall prone and make a Deception (Charisma) check with advantage contested against your opponent’s Passive Insight (10 + their Wisdom modifier). On a success, they believe you were killed and and will behave accordingly. If you attack a deceived creature, you have advantage on the attack roll, and all creatures who can see you are no longer deceived.

description.p: Momma always said you could’ve been an artificer. Maybe if you hadn’t blown up the dormitory, things would’ve gone different.

When you adopt this calling at 3rd level, you become proficient with alchemist’s supplies. If you are already proficient with alchemist’s supplies, you gain proficiency with one other type of artisan’s tools of your choice.

Beginning at 3rd level, whenever you finish a long rest, you can create two bombs of your choice from the bomb table. As an action, you can throw a bomb up to 60 feet away. The bomb explodes on impact, producing the corresponding effect from the table. Bombs that require creatures to make saving throws do so against your grit save DC.
Creating a bomb requires you to have alchemist’s supplies and tinker’s tools on your person, and any bomb you create with this feature lasts until it is used or until the end of your next long rest.
When you reach certain levels in this class, you can make additional bombs at the end of a long rest: four at level 6, six at level 10, and eight at level 15.

sheet.description: Whenever you finish a long rest, you can create {{grenadier:bombs}} bombs of your choice. Bomb save DC {{grit:save-dc}}. Bombs last until used or the end of your next long rest. As an action, you can throw a bomb up to 60 feet away. The bomb explodes on impact, producing the corresponding effect.

description.p: Creates a cloud of smoke that heavily obscures the area in a 20-foot radius sphere for one minute, spreading around corners. A moderate wind disperses the smoke in 4 rounds; a strong wind disperses it in 1 round.

sheet.description: Cloud of smoke that heavily obscures the area in a {{bomb:cloud:radius}}-foot radius sphere for {{bomb:cloud:duration}} minute, spreading around corners.

description.p: Creates an irritating cloud that lightly obscures the area in a 20-foot radius sphere for one minute, spreading around corners. Creatures who enter the area for the first time on a turn or start their turn there must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be blinded for 1 round. A moderate wind disperses the cloud in 4 rounds; a strong wind disperses it in 1 round.

sheet.description: Cloud that lightly obscures the area in a {{bomb:cloud:radius}}-foot radius sphere for {{bomb:cloud:duration}} minute, spreading around corners. Creatures who enter the area for the first time on a turn or start their turn there must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be blinded for 1 round.

description.p: Creates a cloud of yellow nauseating gas in a 20-foot radius sphere for one minute, spreading around corners. Creatures who enter the area for the first time on a turn or start their turn there must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or spend their action coughing on their next turn. A moderate wind disperses the cloud in 4 rounds; a strong wind disperses it in 1 round.

sheet.description: Cloud of yellow nauseating gas in a {{bomb:cloud:radius}}-foot radius sphere for {{bomb:cloud:duration}} minute, spreading around corners. Creatures who enter the area for the first time on a turn or start their turn there must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or spend their action coughing on their next turn.

description.p: Creates a blinding flash of light in a 30-foot radius sphere. All creatures within range must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be blinded until the end of your next turn.

sheet.description: Blinding flash of light in a {{bomb:flash:radius}}-foot radius sphere. Constitution saving throw or be blinded until the end of your next turn.

description.p: Creates a fiery explosion in a 20-foot radius sphere, spreading around corners. All creatures within range must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 6d6 fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a success. On a failed save, a creature continues to burn for 1 minute. At the end of each of their turns, the creature repeats the saving throw. It takes 2d6 fire damage on a failed save, and ends the effect on a success.

sheet.description: Fiery explosion in a {{bomb:cloud:radius}}-foot radius sphere, spreading around corners. Dexterity saving throw, taking 6d6 fire damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a success. On a failed save, a creature continues to burn for {{bomb:cloud:duration}} minute. At the end of each of their turns, the creature repeats the saving throw. It takes 2d6 fire damage on a failed save, and ends the effect on a success.

description.p: Creates an explosion of flying metal in a 20-foot radius sphere. All creatures within range must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 8d6 piercing damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a success.

sheet.description: Explosion of flying metal in a {{bomb:cloud:radius}}-foot radius sphere. All creatures within range must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking 8d6 piercing damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a success.

description.p: Creates an explosion of freezing air and liquid in a 10-foot radius sphere, spreading around corners. All creatures within range must make a Constitution saving throw, taking 1d8 cold damage on a failed save or half as much on a success. On a failed save, a creature’s movement speed is halved for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the condition on a success.

sheet.description: Explosion of freezing air and liquid in a {{bomb:freeze:radius}}-foot radius sphere, spreading around corners. Constitution saving throw, taking 1d8 cold damage on a failed save or half as much on a success. On a failed save, a creature’s movement speed is halved for {{bomb:cloud:duration}} minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the condition on a success.

description.p: At 6th level, when you throw a bomb using your action, you can make one ranged weapon attack as a bonus action.

sheet.description: When you throw a bomb using your action, you can make one ranged weapon attack as a bonus action.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, you can specify a bomb’s trigger when you use it, choosing from the following options:

tr.td: Standard trigger, bomb detonates when it strikes a creature or surface.
The bomb detonates when any creature enters its radius or spends any amount of their movement within its radius.
You can detonate a single bomb using your reaction if you are within 200 feet of it.
The bomb detonates at the start of your turn after a number of rounds of your choosing, up to a maximum of 3.

sheet.description: You can specify a bomb’s trigger when you use it, choosing from the following options: Impact, Proximity, Remote, Timer.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, as an action, you can spend 2 grit points when you make a ranged weapon attack. On a hit, the target takes damage as normal and all creatures within 5 feet must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save a creature takes 2d10 fire damage, or half as much on a success.

sheet.description: When you make a ranged weapon attack, on a hit, the target takes damage as normal and all creatures within 5 feet must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save a creature takes 2d10 fire damage, or half as much on a success.

description.p: Beginning at 15th level, your bomb’s effective radii are doubled, and the duration of your bomb’s effects are doubled.

At 18th level, when you create bombs during a long rest, you can choose to combine the effects of two different bomb types available to you. If you do so, that bomb counts as 2 bombs for the purposes of crafting restrictions. If both bomb effects require a saving throw of the same type, a creature only makes a single save against the effects.

sheet.description: When you create bombs during a long rest, you can choose to combine the effects of two different bomb types available to you. If you do so, that bomb counts as 2 bombs for the purposes of crafting restrictions. If both bomb effects require a saving throw of the same type, a creature only makes a single save against the effects.

description.p: The spin of the chamber. The roll of the dice. Risk and chance are in your bones, whether its at the tavern or on the battlefield. You live for the thrill of the unknown, and surrender yourself to the whims of Fate — until it suits you to take the reigns yourself.
Starting at 3rd level, you can infuse non-magical thrown weapons and ammunition with special magical effects.

When you complete a long rest, you can infuse up to 5 thrown weapons or pieces of ammunition with gambler magic. These infused items constitute your Hand. To infuse an item, roll a d20 for each item and consult the Arcane Gambit table on the next page to see the item’s effect. These items remain infused until you complete a long rest, or the item is used.

description.p: The lawman. The quintessential gunslinger who answers the call to protect the weak and apprehend the vicious.

When you adopt this calling at 3rd level, you learn to summon chains or rope to bind creatures. As a bonus action, you can spend 2 grit points and choose a creature within 30 feet. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be bound by spectral chains shooting out of the ground from a point within your space. The chain’s length is equal to the distance between you and the creature at the time it is bound. A creature cannot move further away from the origin point than the length of the chain.

On its turn, a creature can use its action to make an Athletics (Strength) check, freeing themselves on a success. If a creature is bound by multiple chains, they attempt to break them all at the same time. The DC of the check increases by 2 for each chain they are bound by after the first one.
As a bonus action you can tug on the chain, giving yourself advantage on your next attack roll against that creature until the end of the turn.

The chains last for 1 minute, and you are concentrating on them as if on a spell. As long as you maintain concentration, you can continue to summon additional chains with this feature. If concentration is dropped, all active bindings end.

sheet.description: One creature of your choice within 30 feet must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw (DC {{grit:save-dc}}) or be bound by spectral chains for up to 1 minute (requires concentration). The chain’s length is equal to the distance between you and the creature at the time it is bound. A creature cannot move further away from the origin point than the length of the chain. As a bonus action you can tug on the chain, giving yourself advantage on your next attack roll against that creature until the end of the turn.

description.p: At 6th level, you learn to restrain creatures when you get close. As an action, you can expend 1 grit point and attempt to bind a creature within 5 feet of you. The creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be restrained for one minute.
A creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns, doing so with disadvantage if it is affected by your bindings.

sheet.description: You can attempt to bind a creature within 5 feet of you. The creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be restrained for one minute. A creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns, doing so with disadvantage if it is affected by your bindings.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, you can reel in creatures held by your binding. As an action, you can choose a creature currently affected by your bindings and attempt to move them towards the origin point. The creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 15 feet in a straight line towards the origin point.
The length of the chain decreases by the number of feet the creature moved. If the length of the chain becomes zero, the creature is restrained until they free themselves of the chains.
If a creature is unable to move the full distance for any reason, they take 4d6 bludgeoning damage.

sheet.description: You can choose a creature currently affected by your bindings. The creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 15 feet in a straight line towards the origin point. The length of the chain decreases by the number of feet the creature moved. If the length of the chain becomes zero, the creature is restrained until they free themselves of the chains. If a creature is unable to move the full distance for any reason, they take 4d6 bludgeoning damage.

description.p: Beginning at 15th level, when you hit two creatures within 30 ft of each other using the attack action, you can expend 2 grit points to bind them together with a spectral chain. The chain’s length is equal to the distance between the two creatures at the time of binding. The creatures cannot move farther apart than the length of the chain.

An affected creature can use its action to make a contested Athletics (Strength) check to move the other affected creature 10 feet towards them. A creature can attempt to break the chain by making an Athletics (Strength) check against your grit save DC as an action, freeing both creatures on a success.
You can only have two creatures bound together in this way at a time.

sheet.description: When you hit two creatures within 30 ft of each other using the attack action, you can bind them together with a spectral chain. The chain’s length is equal to the distance between the two creatures at the time of binding. The creatures cannot move farther apart than the length of the chain. You can only have two creatures bound together in this way at a time.

description.p: At 18th Level, you learn how to conjure a prison of metal. As an action, you can expend 3 grit points and choose a point within 60 feet of you. A prison appears at the point you choose; either a solid box or a cage.
A prison in the shape of a cage can be up to 20 feet on a side and is made from 1/2-inch diameter bars spaced 1/2 inch apart.
A prison in the shape of a box can be up to 10 feet on a side, creating a solid barrier that prevents anyone from seeing into or out of it. The area inside is in complete darkness.
The prison has an AC of 17 and 100 hit points. You can dismiss the prison as an action.

sheet.description: Choose a point within 60 feet of you. A prison appears at the point you choose; either a solid box or a cage. The prison has an AC of 17 and 100 hit points. You can dismiss the prison as an action.

description.p: There are a lot of problems you call on a wizard to solve. But when your problem is a wizard, you need a mage hunter. Intelligent and relentless, these gunslingers can make life a living hell for spellcasters that stand in their way.

Beginning at 3rd level, as a bonus action you can spend 1 grit point to designate a creature you can see within 90 feet as your bounty. You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects from your bounty. The bounty lasts until the designated creature dies, or until you spend grit to designate a different bounty.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: You designate a creature you can see within 90 feet as your bounty. You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects from your bounty. The bounty lasts until the designated creature dies, or until you spend grit to designate a different bounty.

description.p: When you adopt this calling at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in one of the following skills: Arcana, Investigation, or Survival.
At 6th level, you learn to detect and influence the flow of magic around you. You can spend 3 grit points to ritually cast dispel magic, and you can spend 1 grit point to cast detect magic.

sheet.description: You can spend 3 grit points to ritually cast dispel magic, and you can spend 1 grit point to cast detect magic.

description.p: Starting at 6th level, when your current bounty drops to 0 hit points, you can end your bounty to regain 1 spent grit point.

sheet.description: When your current bounty drops to 0 hit points, you can end your bounty to regain 1 spent grit point.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, when a creature within 15 feet of you makes a saving throw against a spell or magical effect from your bounty, you can use your reaction to give them advantage on the saving throw.

sheet.description: When a creature within 15 feet of you makes a saving throw against a spell or magical effect from your bounty, you can give them advantage on the saving throw.

description.p: Starting at 15th level, when you make a Wisdom or Charisma saving throw against a spell or magical effect, you can make an Intelligence saving throw instead.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). You regain any expended uses when you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: When you make a Wisdom or Charisma saving throw against a spell or magical effect, you can make an Intelligence saving throw instead.

description.p: Starting at 18th level, if you see your bounty attempting to cast a spell, you can spend 1 grit point to make a ranged weapon attack against them as a reaction. If the attack hits, the creature must succeed on a concentration check or the spell fails.

sheet.description: If you see your bounty attempting to cast a spell, you can make a ranged weapon attack against them. If the attack hits, the creature must succeed on a concentration check or the spell fails.

description.p: You don’t play by the rules; folks in your line of work that do have a nasty tendency of winding up dead. Whether your dirty deads are behind you, before you, or all around you, you’re willing to do whatever it takes to make sure the one walking out of a fight dead ain’t you.
Starting at 3rd level, you are proficient with improvised weapons, and their damage die increases to 1d6. You can make an improvised weapon or unarmed attack as a bonus action.
Your unarmed attacks deal 1d4 bludgeoning, and you can use your Intelligence modifier instead of your Strength or Dexterity when making an unarmed or improvised weapon attack.

sheet.description: You are proficient with improvised weapons, and their damage die increases to 1d6. You can make an improvised weapon or unarmed attack as a bonus action. Your unarmed attacks deal 1d4 bludgeoning, and you can use your Intelligence modifier instead of your Strength or Dexterity when making an unarmed or improvised weapon attack.

description.p: Beginning at 6th level, as a reaction you can grab a creature’s body when they die within 5 feet of you if the creature is Medium or Small and you have an open hand. When someone makes a ranged attack against you, it targets the body instead unless it is a critical hit.

The body has an AC of 10 and hitpoints equal to half of its original hit point maximum. When the body is reduced to 0 hit points, it has suffered too much damage to be usable and no longer protects you. While holding the body, your movement speed is reduced to 0 and you cannot benefit from any bonus to your speed.

description.p: At 10th level, when you hit a creature with an improvised weapon or unarmed attack, that creature cannot take reactions until the start of their next turn.

sheet.description: When you hit a creature with an improvised weapon or unarmed attack, that creature cannot take reactions until the start of their next turn.

description.p: At 15th level, you no longer suffer a penalty to your movement speed as a result of using Meat Shield.

At 15th level, you can use a bonus action to expend 1 grit point to throw dust into the eyes of a creature who is within 5 feet of you. They must make a Dexterity saving throw or be blinded for one minute. The creature can spend an action to remove the dust and end the condition.

sheet.description: You can throw dust into the eyes of a creature who is within 5 feet of you. They must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC {{grit:save-dc}}) or be blinded for one minute. The creature can spend an action to remove the dust and end the condition.

description.p: Beginning at 18th level, you can spend 3 grit points to make an improvised weapon or unarmed attack as an action against a creature. On a hit, the creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or begin suffocating. During this time, the creature cannot breathe or speak, and their movement speed is halved. They remain conscious for a number of rounds equal to 1 plus their Constitution modifier (minimum 1) and can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the condition on a success.

If the creature is unable to end the condition before the determined number of rounds, they immediately become unconscious, but do not drop to 0 hit points. Lesser Restoration or similar magic immediately ends the suffocation.

During this time, the creature cannot breathe or speak, and their movement speed is halved. They remain conscious for a number of rounds equal to 1 plus their Constitution modifier (minimum 1) and can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the condition on a success.

description.p: There’s a certain peace you feel in that moment between the click of the hammer and the roar of the powder. Every single grain releasing it’s strength in one mighty effort, then consumed in a violent flame.
You harness the elemental forces to enhance your abilities in battle, spitting fire, frost, or whatever you need from the muzzle of your weapon.

When you reach 3rd level, you augment your gunslinging prowess with the ability to cast spells. See chapter 10 of the PHB for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the sorcerer spell list.
You learn three cantrips of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. You learn an additional sorcerer cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

The Powder Mage Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your sorcerer spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell shield and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast shield using either slot.

You know three 1st-level sorcerer spells of your choice, two of which you must choose from the evocation and transmutation spells on the sorcerer spell list. The Spells Known column of the Powder Mage Spellcasting table shows when you learn more sorcerer spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be an evocation or transmutation spell of your choice, and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.
The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can come from any school of magic.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the sorcerer spells you know with another spell of your choice from the sorcerer spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be am evocation or transmutation spell, unless you’re replacing the spell you gained at 3rd, 8th, 14th, or 20th level from any school of magic.

Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, since you are using your grit to utilize your innate magic. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when making an attack roll with a wizard spell. Any spell that refers to your Spell save DC uses your Grit save DC.
Spell Save DC (your Grit Save DC) = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

Starting at 3rd level, as a bonus action, you can expend 1 spell slot without casting a spell to strengthen your next attack. The next time you cast a leveled spell during the next hour, the spell is upcast by a number of spell levels equal to the level of the expended spell slot.

sheet.description: You can expend 1 spell slot without casting a spell. The next time you cast a leveled spell during the next hour, the spell is upcast by a number of spell levels equal to the level of the expended spell slot.

description.p: Beginning at 6th level, you gain the ability to change the damage type of your ranged weapon attacks. When making a ranged weapon attack, you can choose to change the damage type to acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage.

sheet.description: When making a ranged weapon attack, you can choose to change the damage type to acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage.

description.p: Starting at 10th level, your ranged weapon attacks hinder a creature’s ability to withstand your spells. When you hit a creature with a ranged weapon attack, that creature has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes against a spell you cast until the end of your next turn.

sheet.description: When you hit a creature with a ranged weapon attack, that creature has disadvantage on the next saving throw it makes against a spell you cast until the end of your next turn.

description.p: Starting at 15th level, when you make a ranged weapon attack that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage as part of the Attack action, you add your Intelligence modifier to the damage dealt.
You also add your Intelligence modifier to the acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage dealt by any cantrip.

sheet.description: When you make a ranged weapon attack that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage as part of the Attack action, you add {{intelligence:modifier}} damage. You also add {{intelligence:modifier}} to the acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage dealt by any cantrip.

description.p: At 18th level, you learn how to effortlessly weave magic between shots. When you take the Attack action, you can spend 2 grit points to cast a single cantrip as a bonus action.

sheet.description: When you take the Attack action, you can cast a single cantrip as a bonus action.

description.p: "The gods reward devotion. They do not discriminate against upbringing, nor do they disparage the simple-minded. Nay, it is often among those most lowly of folk where you find the sincerest faith.
But make no mistake, these people are my flock and I will strike the head from any foul creature which seeks to defile this congregation."
— Dram Krautur, half-orc Preacher

When you reach 3rd level, you augment your gunslinging prowess with the ability to cast spells. See chapter 10 of the PHB for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the cleric spell list.
You learn two cantrips of your choice from the cleric spell list. You learn an additional cleric cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

The Preacher Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your cleric spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of cleric spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the cleric spell list. When you do so, choose a number of cleric spells equal to the half your proficiency modifier, rounded down, plus your intelligence modifier. The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell bless and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast bless using either slot.

For example, if you are a 7rd-level Preacher, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With an Intelligence of 16 and a proficiency modifier of 3, your list of prepared spells can include four spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell cure wounds, you can cast it using a 1st-level or 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn’t remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of cleric spells requires time spent in prayer, study, and meditation on spiritual scriptures: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your cleric spells, since you are learning your spells through diligent study of your faith. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when making an attack roll with a wizard spell. Any spell that refers to your Spell save DC uses your Grit save DC.
Spell Save DC (your Grit Save DC) = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
At 3rd level, you learn how to perform religious rites to bestow the blessing of your god. As part of a long rest, you can conduct a 10 minute ritual on a willing creature.

Choose a blessing from the list below. A blessing lasts until you take another long rest. Blessings are powered by the preacher’s divine die, a d4. This die changes as shown in the Divine Die column of the Preacher Spellcasting table.
When a creature with this blessing makes an attack roll you can see, you can use your reaction and expend 1 grit point to roll your divine die and add it to the attack roll.
When a creature with this blessing is targeted by an attack roll that you can see, you can use your reaction and expend 1 grit point to roll your divine die and add it to the target’s AC.
When a creature with this blessing would regain hit points, you can expend 1 grit point and roll your divine die and add it to the amount of hit points the target regains.

Beginning at 6th level, once per turn when you deal damage with a ranged weapon, you can deal additional radiant damage equal to your proficiency modifier.

sheet.description: Once per turn when you deal damage with a ranged weapon, you can deal an additional {{proficiency}} radiant damage.

description.p: At 10th level, your divine die increases to a d6, and your Blessings impart greater benefits.

description.p: As an action, you can expend 2 grit points and recite a prayer of blessing for up to one minute. While praying, all creatures within 20 feet of you are considered blessed with every divine blessing. When a creature leaves the aura, all blessings conferred upon it by this feature end. You are concentrating on this ability as though it was a spell.

sheet.description: You recite a prayer of blessing for up to 1 minute (concentration). While praying, all creatures within 20 feet of you are considered blessed with every divine blessing. When a creature leaves the aura, all blessings conferred upon it by this feature end.

description.p: Lots of folk claim that fighting’s in their blood. In your case, it’s more literal than most.
Starting at 3rd level, you can ritualistically expend your vigor to curse weapons and ammunition.

When you finish a long rest, you can reduce your hit point maximum to imbue your weapons and ammunition with terrible curses, according to the Curse table below. Each individual item you curse reduces your maximum hit points by 5, and can only have one curse applied to it at a time. You cannot use this feature to reduce your maximum hit points below half of your original hit point maximum.
Each item remains cursed until it is used to apply the curse, or you finish a long rest; at which point your hit point maximum returns to its original value.
